title: Diary of an Overland Journey from Bombay to England, and of a year's residence in Great Britain
author: Khurshed-ji, ARDSHER
snippet: (41.)—Edinburgh or Mid Lothian, a county of Scotland, about thirty mileslong, and in breadth from sixteen to twenty: its superficial extent is 360square miles, or 230,400 English acres; it is bounded north by the Firth ofForth, and the Almond which separates it from West Lothian or Linlithgowshire, east by the county of Haddington, south by the counties of Lanark,Peebles and Berwick, and on the west corner by part ofthe County of Linlithgow; the general aspect is pleasant; about one third consists of arableland, fertile, and highly cultivated, and affords excellent crops; the Moorfootand the Pentland Hills pass through the county, the highest point of whichrises 1700 feet above the level of the sea. This county abounds in most partswith Coal, Limestone, Freestone, and Iron ore of different species : the principal rivers ofthe county are the north and south Esk, the Almond and thewater of Leith : besides Edinburgh the metropolis of the county, and Leith,the county contains the towns and villages of Dalkeith, Musselburg, PortoBello, Lasswade, Pennycuich, Midcalder, Gilmerton, and New Haven, where

title: The Black Douglas
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: And ever as he gazed at her the Earl of Douglas grew more and more inlove with the Lady Sybilla. There was no covert side through which aburn plunged downward from the steep side of Moorfoot, but theywandered it alone together. Early and late they might have been met,he with his face turned upon her, and she looking straight forwardwith the same inscrutable calm.

title: The Black Douglas
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: And ever as he gazed at her the Earl of Douglas grew more and more inlove with the Lady Sybilla. There was no covert side through which aburn plunged downward from the steep side of Moorfoot, but theywandered it alone together. Early and late they might have been met,he with his face turned upon her, and she looking straight forwardwith the same inscrutable calm.

title: Cleg Kelly, arab of the city,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: He had been feeling for some time a growing coolness somewhere. But at this point the water in the sink ran over on the floor, and he turned round to discover that he had been sitting in a full trough of excellent Moorfoot water, with the spigot running  briskly down his back all the while.

title: The Black Douglas ... Second impression.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: And ever as he gazed at her the Earl of Douglas grewmore and more in love with the Lady Sybilla. Therewas no covert side through which a burn plunged downward from the steep side of Moorfoot, but they wandered it alone together. Early and late they might havebeen met, he with his face turned upon her, and she looking straight forward with the same inscrutable calm.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: He had been feelingfor some time a growing coolness somewhere. But at thispoint the water in the sink ran over on the floor, and heturned round to discover that he had been sitting in a fulltrough of excellent Moorfoot water, with the spigot running briskly down his back all the while.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: feeling for some time a growing coolness somewhere. But at this point the water in the sink ran over onthe floor, and he turned round to discover that he hadbeen sitting in a full trough of excellent Moorfootwater, with the spigot running briskly down his backall the while.

title: The Black Douglas
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: It was in the gracious fulness of the early autumn, when the sheaveswere set up in many a park and little warded holt about the Moorfootbraes, that William Douglas and Sybilla de Thouars stood together upona crest of hill, crowned with dwarf birch and thick foliaged alder--aplace in the retirement of whose sylvan bower they had already spentmany tranced hours.
